game module

class game.Game[source]

Bases: object

class Game[source]

Bases: object

Class representing the game logic and component management.

Parameters:

  • (int) (players_colors_length) – The width of the game area.

  • (int) – The height of the game area.

  • (list) (players_to_remove) – A list of Player objects representing the players in the game.

  • (list) – A list of Obstacle objects representing the obstacles in the game.

  • (list) – A list of Bullet objects representing the fired bullets in the game.

  • (int) – The number of available colors for players.

  • (list) – A list of players to be removed from the game.

add_new_obstacle(id)[source]

Add a new obstacle to the game.

id (int): The ID of the obstacle.

Returns:

dict: A dictionary containing information about the added obstacle, including its type, position, and ID.

add_player(player_name: str, websocket)[source]

Add a new player to the game.

Parameters:

  • (str) (player_name) – The name of the player.

  • websocket – The WebSocket associated with the player.

Returns:

(dict) A dictionary containing information about the success of the operation and game state.

check_for_bullet_obstacle_collision()[source]

Check for collisions between bullets and obstacles.

Returns:

tuple[list[dict], list[int], list[Obstacle]]: A tuple containing a list of damaged obstacles,

a list of bullet IDs, and a list of new obstacles to be added.

check_for_bullet_player_collision()[source]

Check for collisions between bullets and players.

Returns:

tuple[list[dict], list[int]]: A tuple containing a list of damaged players and a list of bullet IDs.

check_for_collisions(name)[source]

Check for collisions between game objects and handle them.

Parameters:

(str) (name) – The name of the player to check collisions for.

Returns:

bool: True if a collision with an obstacle occurs, False otherwise.

check_for_obstacle_player_collision(player)[source]

Check for collisions between players and obstacles.

Parameters:

(Player) (player) – The player to check collisions for.

Returns:

bool: True if a collision with an obstacle occurs, False otherwise.

check_for_player_player_collision(player)[source]

Check for collisions between players and handle them.

Parameters:

(Player) (player) – The player to check collisions for.

circle_collide(obj1, obj2)[source]

Check if two circular objects collide.

Parameters:

  • obj1 – The first object to check.

  • obj2 – The second object to check.

Returns:

bool: True if the objects collide, False otherwise.

closest_point_on_segment(c, v1, v2)[source]

Find the closest point on a line segment to a given point.

Parameters:

  • (dict) (v2) – The coordinates of the point, with keys ‘x’ and ‘y’.

  • (dict) – The coordinates of the first endpoint of the line segment, with keys ‘x’ and ‘y’.

  • (dict) – The coordinates of the second endpoint of the line segment, with keys ‘x’ and ‘y’.

Returns:

tuple[float, float]: The coordinates of the closest point on the line segment.

distance(p1, p2)[source]

Calculate the distance between two points in 2D space.

Parameters:

  • (dict) (p2) – The coordinates of the first point, with keys ‘x’ and ‘y’.

  • (dict) – The coordinates of the second point, with keys ‘x’ and ‘y’.

Returns:

float: The distance between the two points.

dot_product(vector1, vector2)[source]
find_object_by_property(prop_name, prop_value, object_type)[source]

Method used to find object by its property -> it should be unique

prop_name (string): name of the property for eg. “name” prop_value (Any): value of the property for eg. “Tom” object_type (string): one of the game objects: ‘obstacle’, ‘bullet’, ‘player’

Returns:

Reference to the object with the property that we are looking for

find_player_id_by_name(name)[source]
find_random_not_occupied_position()[source]

Find a random position in the game that is not occupied by any obstacles.

Returns:

tuple[int, int]: The x and y coordinates of the randomly generated position.

generate_obstacles(num_obstacles)[source]

Generate a specified number of obstacles.

num_obstacles (int): The number of obstacles to generate.

Returns:

list[Obstacle]: A list of generated obstacles.

Note:

The method ensures that the generated obstacles do not collide with each other.

polygons_collide(obj1, obj2)[source]

Check if two polygons collide with each other.

Parameters:

  • (Obstacle) (obj2) – The first polygon object.

  • (Obstacle) – The second polygon object.

Returns:

bool: True if the polygons collide, False otherwise.

project_polygon(axis, vertices)[source]

Project a polygon onto an axis and determine the minimum and maximum values.

axis (dict): The axis to project onto, with keys ‘x’ and ‘y’. vertices (list[dict]): The vertices of the polygon, each with keys ‘x’ and ‘y’.

Returns:

tuple[float, float]: The minimum and maximum values of the projected polygon on the axis.

there_is_such_player(player_name: str)[source]

Check if a player with the given name already exists in the game.

Parameters:

(str) (player_name) – The name of the player to check.

Returns:

bool: True if a player with the given name already exists, False otherwise.

update_player_position(name, position)[source]

Update the position of a player in the game.

Parameters:

  • (str) (name) – The name of the player to update.

  • (dict) (position) – The new position of the player.
